climbs.name: Eternal Darkness
climbs.fa: September 2020 Brent Nixon, Lisa Newhook, Sean Draper, Kate Knaus

content.description:
From Lake Of The Woods in Cathedral Provincial Park core area, take the Goat Lake Trail 5 km to Goat Lake. Easily hike along the right side of the lake to it's end and contour up rightward through large talus and meadows into the beautiful Larch filled basin below Macabre Tower. The start of the route is above treeline at the head of a scree/talus slope. Snow will linger here late into summer.  Note: the last water trickles from a small meadow stream in the bottom of the baisin unless there is snow.  The route is located on the north face of Macabre Tower. Start left of centre on the face climbing blocky, orange rock. Nice featured climbing on solid stone leads to a good belay ledge. Pitch 1: 5.6, 50m Blocky, orange granite lead slightly rightward up an obvious weakness. Belay on a good ledge with good gear.
Pitch 2: 5.10c, 55m Easy climbing (5.4) trends up left to a short, steep corner (10c). Find a nice small belay ledge with good gear above.
Pitch 3: 5.7, 30m Continue straight up. Belay on a terrace.
Pitch 4: 3rd, 50m Move belay rightward to base of obvious grey dike.
Pitch 5: 5.10d, 30m Cool grey dike features vertical to slightly overhanging moves. Belay left in a vertical wall above on good gear. Option: scramble loose boulders and dirt up around right, traversing into the top of this pitch.
Pitch 6: 5.9, 40m Climb the vertical wall on your left up to the crest. Head up the crest straight to where the climbing gets easier in some large blocks. Belay on a good ledge just above the easy climbing.
Pitch 7: 5.10c, 45m Head rightward and up through blocky climbing, aiming for a big dark corner. Up the obvious big corner with good gear. Belay on top at a good stance.
Pitch 8: 5.7, 55m Continue up leftward then straight upward towards fun blocky climbing. Aim for the summit. Belay on a nice small ledge with good gear.
Pitch 9: 5.6, 60m Climb fun, easy, blocky, rock straight upwards toward the summit. Full 60m pitch. A crack near the summit has a rap anchor and takes excellent gear.   Descent: Rappel from the summit slightly skiers left, towards the large terrace and gully below. Four 60m rappels lead into the snow/dirt gully where you can walk down and circle, skiers right, back under the face to the start. Rap anchors consist of various combinations of pins and nuts equalized with cord and a maillon.  Standard double rack 1/2"-3". Extra tat and some pins for rap anchors that might need to be fortified.

climbs.name: Loose Caboose
climbs.fa: September 2020 Brent Nixon, Lisa Newhook, Sean Draper, Kate Knaus

content.description:
Located on Boxcar Mountain southeast above Goat Lake. From Lake Of The Woods in Cathedral Provincial Park core area, take the Goat Lake Trail 5 km to Goat Lake. Easily hike along the right side of the lake to it's end and continue past the lake angling left across a gravel fan towards Denture Ridge.  Pick a route up the steep loose scree and talus southeast of the lake aiming for a buttress on the left (maybe 200m) before the top of Denture Ridge. The route begins on the right side of the buttress at the top of a small talus and grass cone at a prominent right-to-left crack-dike feature (see photo). Excellent rock in a sunny position high above Goat Lake. Views are fantastic. The pitch 5 parallel, splitter cracks were a gem to find. The 5.11c pitch has a crack for gear on the left that requires a nut tool to excavate placements higher up. A variation to the left from the 11c belay, Needs More Cowbell 5.9, goes around the 11c pitch meeting back on route higher up. Pitch 1: 5.7, 40m Diagonal up leftward following the natural rock features and great holds to a perfect small ledge and excellent gear for a belay.
Pitch 2: 5.7, 40m Continue up left following the same rock feature into more of a chimney/gully feature to a v-crack. Follow the right angling v-crack up to a small belay ledge with good gear.
Pitch 3: 5.11c, 40m Head up to the right into an obvious, beautiful, right-facing corner. Straight up the corner capped by a small 2ft roof with a splitter 10c finger crack leading the way straight above into a chimney. Exit the chimney leftward, belaying on a slopey ledge.
Pitch 4: 5.6, 10m Move the belay leftward and up to an obvious big comfortable belay ledge with great gear.
Pitch 5: 5.8, 55m Straight up twin, splitter cracks to a slabby right-facing corner. Continue straight up into broken, ledgy terrain. Find a comfortable ledge to belay.
Pitch 6: 5.2, 40m Stay left, climbing upward towards the summit ridge. Access the ridge via the top of a broken, loose gully on the left. Belay off blocks on the summit ridge.    Descent: Hike off. Once on the massive flat summit area, head left (northward) contouring for 1-2 km to join up with the Boxcar Mountain trail. Its easy, open alpine terrain. Once on the trail, motor back downhill to the Goat Lake trail. There's water in a great little meadow creek about 1/2 way down the trail.  Standard double rack 0.5"-3"

climbs.name: Needs More Cowbell
climbs.fa: September 2020 Sean Draper and Kate Knaus

content.description:
Located on Boxcar Mountain southeast above Goat Lake. From Lake Of The Woods in Cathedral Provincial Park core area, take the Goat Lake Trail 5 km to Goat Lake. Easily hike along the right side of the lake to it's end and continue past the lake angling left across a gravel fan towards Denture Ridge.  Pick a route up the steep loose scree and talus southeast of the lake aiming for a buttress on the left (maybe 200m) before the top of Denture Ridge. The route begins on the right side of the buttress at the top of a small talus and grass cone at a prominent right-to-left crack-dike feature (see photo). Excellent rock in a sunny position high above Goat Lake. Views are fantastic. The pitch 4 and 5, splitter cracks were a gem to find. This route is a fun, easier 2-pitch variation that traverses left on pitch 3. The route joins back into Loose Caboose 11c on the large pitch 4 belay ledge. Refer to Loose Caboose for more beta and photos. Pitch 1: 5.7, 40m Diagonal up leftward following the natural rock features and great holds to a perfect small ledge and excellent gear for a belay.
Pitch 2: 5.7, 40m Continue up left following the same rock feature into more of a chimney/gully feature to a v-crack. Follow the right angling v-crack up to a small belay ledge with good gear.
Pitch 3: 5.7, 30m Climb straight up an arete feature for 15ft to where a ledge allows you to traverse hard left. Vertical cracks in the wall in front of you offer good pro. Angle down slightly to a right facing corner feature, then climb that up to a nice belay ledge.
Pitch 4: 5.8+, 30m Climb straight up on large blocks to a nice crack in the face leading to a great ledge with a good gear belay.
Pitch 5: 5.8, 55m Straight up twin, splitter cracks to a slabby right-facing corner. Continue straight up into broken, ledgy terrain. Find a comfortable ledge to belay.
Pitch 6: 5.2, 40m Stay left, climbing upward towards the summit ridge. Access the ridge via the top of a broken, loose gully on the left. Belay off blocks on the summit ridge.    Descent: Hike off. Once on the massive flat summit area, head left (northward) contouring for 1-2 km to join up with the Boxcar Mountain trail. Its easy, open alpine terrain. Once on the trail, motor back downhill to the Goat Lake trail. There's water in a great little meadow creek about 1/2 way down the trail. Standard double rack 0.5" to 3"

climbs.name: Patio Seating
climbs.fa: September 2020 Sean Draper, Kate Knaus, Brent Nixon and Lisa Newhook.

content.description:
From the south end of Goat Lake, angle left across a gravel fan towards the steep scree and talus slopes below Denture Ridge. Pick the best line to ascend scree and talus up to the crest of Denture Ridge. Erosion changes the slope every year and not enough foot traffic exists to beat-in a path. Snow will linger high on this slope where the angle eases off until mid-summer. Once in the pass on Denture Ridge, drop down 50m on the other side. Traverse left on ledges where you can below the rock wall above, continuing down and left on connecting ledges until on the southside. Obvious cracks and multiple short multipitch variations litter this sunny, south wall.  The valley south is Ewart Creek containing an old trail connecting west over to Wall Creek. Cross-country travel is easy here with open, alpine, meadow slopes and open, parkland-type forest. At the head of Ewart Creek, directly west, lies The Deacon with a couple of nice alpine rock climbs. Looking south - you are looking directly into the USA and you can even see the border cut-line in the trees at places. A beautiful, sunny, south facing route with great views over the Pasayten Wilderness. The climb starts with some light alpine shrub wrestling to access the 2 longer crack pitches. Belays are on great ledges and gear is plentiful everywhere. Belay off a big boulder at the top. The route starts off from an open ledge in a 5.7 crack, leading up onto a ledge with small alpine trees and krumholtz. Pitch 1: 5.7, 20m Climb nice clean rock straight up to a treed ledge. Wrestle through the krumholtz and trees to a nice crack, left, on the back wall. Belay off a tree.
Pitch 2: 5.10a, 50m Head straight up the nice crack/corner using crack and stemming to a nice big ledge. Belay off a tree or gear.
Pitch 3: 5.10c, 50m From the left side of the ledge find a nice crack shooting upward. Climb this crack with great gear. A bit lichen'y but the gear and jams are good. Reach a small ledge and continue above on 5.7 terrain to the top of the wall. Belay on a boulder or gear. Variation: Kate and Sean climbed 2 pitches of nice 5.7-5.8 cracks 20m left of this route, joining into pitch 3 at the 5.7 section above. Descent: the top is a big flat grassy area. Walk up and west to the edge of the wall over looking directly above Denture Ridge. One-two double rope rappels lead directly back into the pass on Denture Ridge. Look for rap anchors with pins, nuts, and cord.  Standard double rack 0.5" to 3"

Goat Lake is an incredibly beautiful alpine lake surrounded by towering granite walls - complete with mountain goats frolicking in the meadows. Much of the area is completely unexplored with respect to climbing due to it's difficult access and remoteness. Access can be greatly enhanced by hiring the Cathedral Lakes Lodge Jeep to drive you up to the core area. From there, three campsites are a short walk from the lodge, offering amazing lakeside camping in the sub-alpine. You can not camp at Goat Lake but it is only a 4.5km easy hike from Lake Of The Woods camp.

The area has that dry, Okanagan feel, while maintaining lush alpine meadows and lakes full of trout. Buy a fishing license and bring a rod to catch your supper on a rest day. The Lodge is also a very short walk from the campsites if you feel like strolling over for dinner or just enjoying a beer on the patio.

The rock is typically excellent quality granite with corners, slabs, and splitter cracks. Depending on aspect, the rock ranges from completely clean to completely lichen covered. Sunny exposures provide beautiful rock with little cleaning required to climb. You need a sense of adventure considering this is full alpine rock climbing with barely any routes. The climbing presents the full scope of normal alpine rock hazards including, loose rock, rockfall, snow slopes, and vegetated climbing.
